description: Measures how well a solar panel is performing relative to its rated power.
definition: PPR = \frac{MeasuredPowerW}{PowerRatedW} \times 100\%, \text{where MeasuredPowerW is the measured power output and PowerRatedW is the rated power of the panel.}

description: Calculates the percentage of efficiency loss per year for a solar panel.
definition: PELR = \frac{CurrentEfficiencyPercent - InitialEfficiencyPercent}{Years\_Since\_Installation} \times 100\%, \text{where CurrentEfficiencyPercent is obtained from efficiency_profile.current_efficiency.curreffpct.}

description: Quantifies the impact of temperature on panel performance based on its temperature coefficient.
definition: TPCI = PowerRatedW \times TempCoef \times (CellTempC - 25), \text{where TempCoef is the temperature coefficient and 25°C is the standard test condition temperature.}

description: Measures the overall energy production efficiency considering all losses.
definition: EPE = PPR \times (1 - SoilingLossPercent/100) \times (1 - CumulativeDegradationPercent/100), \text{where PPR is the Panel Performance Ratio.}

description: Calculates the energy lost due to inverter inefficiency.
definition: IEL = MeasuredPowerW \times (1 - InverterEfficiencyPercent/100), \text{where InverterEfficiencyPercent is from power_metrics.inverteffpct.}

description: Calculates the rate at which the fill factor of a panel is degrading over time.
definition: FFDR = \frac{FillFactorInitial - FillFactorCurrent}{Years\_Since\_Installation} \times 100\%, \text{where FillFactorInitial and FillFactorCurrent are from the electrical table.}

description: Quantifies the impact of soiling on power production based on dust density.
definition: SIF = SoilingLossPercent / DustDensityGM2, \text{where higher values indicate greater sensitivity to dust accumulation.}

description: Evaluates the cost-effectiveness of maintenance relative to the plant's capacity.
definition: MCE = \frac{MaintenanceCostUSD + CleaningCostUSD + ReplacementCostUSD}{GenCapMW}, \text{where lower values indicate more cost-effective maintenance.}

description: Calculates the revenue loss per MW of capacity due to maintenance issues.
definition: RLR = \frac{RevenueLossUSD}{GenCapMW}, \text{where higher values indicate greater financial impact from downtime.}

description: Measures how effectively the panel converts available solar irradiance to power.
definition: IUR = \frac{MeasuredPowerW / PanelAreaM2}{POAIrradianceWM2}, \text{where POAIrradianceWM2 is from irradiance_conditions.irradiance_types[3] and PanelAreaM2 is the area of the panel.}

description: Defines when a panel's performance has degraded to a level requiring attention.
definition: A solar panel is considered below critical performance threshold when its Panel Performance Ratio (PPR) falls below 80% of the expected value for its age, accounting for normal degradation.

description: Indicates conditions that suggest a panel may be developing hot spots.
definition: A panel is at risk for hot spots when it shows irregular electrical parameters (Voc or Isc deviations >5% compared to other panels in the same string) combined with cell temperatures exceeding 20°C above ambient temperature.

description: Defines when panel cleaning should be performed based on soiling conditions.
definition: Cleaning should be performed when Soiling Loss Percentage exceeds 5% or when Dust Density exceeds 0.15 g/m², whichever occurs first.

description: Defines criteria for determining when a panel should be considered for replacement.
definition: A panel has reached effective end-of-life when its cumulative degradation exceeds 20% or when maintenance costs in a 12-month period exceed 30% of replacement value.

description: Defines the environmental conditions for optimal panel performance.
definition: The optimal performance window occurs when cell temperature is between 25-45°C, POA irradiance exceeds 800 W/m², and soiling loss is less than 2%.

description: Identifies when panels in a string have mismatched electrical characteristics.
definition: A string has significant mismatch when the standard deviation of current measurements (Imp or Isc) across panels exceeds 3% of the mean value under the same irradiance conditions.

description: Criteria for when warranty claims should be initiated based on performance degradation.
definition: A warranty claim should be considered when a panel's Energy Production Efficiency falls more than 10% below the manufacturer's warranty curve for its age, with at least three consecutive measurements confirming the underperformance.

description: Classifies environmental conditions based on their potential impact on solar plant operations.
definition: A composite index calculated from extreme values of temperature, humidity, wind speed, and precipitation, where higher values indicate more severe operating conditions and increased risk of performance issues.

description: Measures the contribution of the inverter to grid stability.
definition: A metric determined by the combination of Power Quality Index, Harmonic Distortion Percentage, and Power Factor, where values closer to 1.0 indicate better contribution to grid stability.

description: Illustrates the rated power output of solar panels.
definition: Measured in watts (W), representing the maximum power output a panel can produce under Standard Test Conditions (STC). Values typically range from 250W for older models to 650W for newer high-efficiency panels.

description: Illustrates the efficiency of solar panels in converting sunlight to electricity.
definition: Expressed as a percentage, representing how much of the sun's energy hitting the panel is converted to electricity. Modern panels typically range from 15% to 23%, with premium models reaching up to 25%.

description: Illustrates how panel performance changes with temperature.
definition: Expressed as a percentage per degree Celsius (usually negative), indicating how much a panel's power output decreases for each degree above 25°C. Typical values range from -0.25% to -0.50% per °C, with lower absolute values indicating better high-temperature performance.

description: Illustrates the operating temperature of solar cells.
definition: Measured in degrees Celsius, representing the actual temperature of the solar cells during operation. Typically ranges from 40°C to 70°C depending on ambient conditions and panel design, with temperatures above 80°C potentially causing accelerated degradation.

description: Illustrates the ratio of actual maximum power to theoretical power.
definition: A dimensionless value between 0 and 1 representing the ratio of maximum power point (Vmp × Imp) to open-circuit voltage times short-circuit current (Voc × Isc). High-quality commercial panels typically have fill factors between 0.75 and 0.85.

description: Illustrates the power loss due to dirt and dust accumulation.
definition: Expressed as a percentage of power output lost due to soiling. Clean panels have values near 0%, while heavily soiled panels in dusty environments may experience losses exceeding 15%. Typical values in maintained systems range from 2% to 5%.

description: Illustrates the yearly performance degradation of solar panels.
definition: Expressed as a percentage, representing how much a panel's output decreases per year. Quality silicon panels typically degrade at 0.5% to 0.7% annually, while lower quality or certain thin-film technologies may degrade at rates above 1% annually.

description: Illustrates the total performance loss over a panel's lifetime.
definition: Expressed as a percentage, representing total performance degradation since installation. New panels start at 0%, while panels approaching end-of-life may have values of 15-20% or higher, with manufacturer warranties typically covering degradation up to 20% over 25 years.

description: Illustrates the solar energy available to panels in their installed orientation.
definition: Measured in watts per square meter (W/m²), representing the solar energy reaching the panel surface. Typical daytime values range from 200 W/m² on heavily overcast days to 1000+ W/m² under clear sky conditions at solar noon.

description: Illustrates the efficiency of inverters in converting DC to AC power.
definition: Expressed as a percentage, representing how much DC power from panels is successfully converted to AC power. Modern string inverters typically operate at 96-98% efficiency, while microinverters may range from 94-97% efficiency.

description: Enhances the Panel Performance Ratio by accounting for temperature effects.
definition: TAPR = PPR + (TPCI / PowerRatedW), where PPR is the Panel Performance Ratio and TPCI is the Temperature Performance Coefficient Impact.

description: Calculates the combined power losses from all major sources.
definition: TSL = (PowerRatedW × CumDegPct/100) + (MeasuredPowerW × SoilingLossPct/100) + IEL, where IEL is the Inverter Efficiency Loss and CumDegPct is from efficiency_profile.degradation.cumdegpct.

description: Evaluates the financial return of maintenance activities.
definition: MROI = RLR / MCE, where RLR is the Revenue Loss Rate and MCE is the Maintenance Cost Efficiency. Higher values indicate better return on maintenance investments.

description: Comprehensive metric that accounts for all factors affecting panel performance.
definition: EPI = PPR × (1 - TSL/PowerRatedW) × (IUR/PaneEffPct), where PPR is the Panel Performance Ratio, TSL is the Total System Loss, and IUR is the Irradiance Utilization Ratio.

description: Compares panel degradation to expected rates based on panel type and age.
definition: NDI = PELR / AnnDegRate, where PELR is the Panel Efficiency Loss Rate and AnnDegRate is from efficiency_profile.degradation.anndegrate. Values above 1.0 indicate faster than expected degradation.

description: Adjusts panel efficiency measurements to account for weather conditions.
definition: WCE = CurrentEfficiencyPercent × (1 + TempCoef × (25 - CellTempC) / 100) × (1000 / POAIrradianceWM2), where CurrentEfficiencyPercent is from efficiency_profile.current_efficiency.curreffpct.

description: Calculates the expected energy production considering current conditions.
definition: EEY = PowerRatedW × EPE × SIF × POAIrradianceWM2 / 1000, where EPE is the Energy Production Efficiency and SIF is the Soiling Impact Factor.

description: Measures the overall quality of power delivered to the grid.
definition: GIQ = PWRQualIDX × (1 - power_metrics.harmdistpct/100) × power_metrics.invertpowfac, using PWRQualIDX from the inverter table.

description: Measures the combined degradation of electrical parameters.
definition: EDI = (FillFactorInitial - FillFactorCurrent)/FillFactorInitial + (VocInitialV - VocCurrV)/VocInitialV + (IscInitialA - IscCurrA)/IscInitialA, where higher values indicate more severe degradation.

description: Calculates the financial cost of degradation over time.
definition: FID = GenCapMW × 1000 × NDI × PELR × ElectricityPricePerKWh × 24 × 365, where NDI is the Normalized Degradation Index and PELR is the Panel Efficiency Loss Rate.

description: Identifies panels showing accelerated degradation requiring intervention.
definition: A panel requires urgent attention when its Normalized Degradation Index exceeds 1.5 and its TAPR is below the Critical Performance Threshold.

description: Identifies panels that would benefit most from premium maintenance services.
definition: A panel is considered a premium maintenance candidate when its Maintenance Return on Investment exceeds 2.0 and its Energy Production Efficiency is below 90% but above 75%.

description: Determines the ideal cleaning frequency based on environmental conditions and soiling rates.
definition: Cleaning should be scheduled when SIF × DustDensityGM2 exceeds the Soiling Cleaning Threshold or when Expected Energy Yield is reduced by more than 3% due to soiling.

description: Identifies weather patterns that pose significant risk to panel performance or longevity.
definition: Weather conditions are considered high-risk when the Weather Severity Index exceeds 7.0 and Cell Temperature exceeds the upper limit of the Optimal Performance Window.

description: Strategy for optimizing panel replacements near warranty expiration.
definition: Panels should be evaluated for warranty claims when approaching warranty expiration if their Normalized Degradation Index exceeds 0.9 or if they fail to meet the Warranty Claim Threshold criteria.

description: Classification system for the quality of power exported to the grid.
definition: Power export quality is classified as 'Premium' when Grid Integration Quality exceeds 0.95, 'Standard' when between 0.90 and 0.95, and 'Substandard' when below 0.90, with substandard exports potentially subject to utility penalties.

description: Identifies plants that would benefit most from component upgrades.
definition: A plant qualifies as an upgrade candidate when the Financial Impact of Degradation exceeds 10% of replacement cost and Effective Performance Index is below 0.85 for three consecutive months.

description: Assesses the compatibility between panels and their connected inverters.
definition: An inverter-panel combination is considered optimally compatible when the panel's Weather Corrected Efficiency stays within 5% of the manufacturer's specifications and the inverter's Inverter Efficiency Percentage exceeds 97%.

description: Categorizes the level of environmental stress a panel is experiencing.
definition: Environmental stress is classified based on combining Weather Severity Index and exposure time outside the Optimal Performance Window, with high stress potentially accelerating the Panel Efficiency Loss Rate.

description: Holistic economic assessment of a solar installation.
definition: A comprehensive economic evaluation combining Maintenance Return on Investment, Financial Impact of Degradation, and revenue generation adjusted by the Effective Performance Index, providing a single metric for financial performance.

description: Four-tier system prioritizing maintenance actions based on combined financial and operational factors
definition: URGENT: Having critical alerts AND MROI>2.0; HIGH: Having critical alerts; MEDIUM: MROI>2.0; LOW: All other cases

description: Combined conditions that determine when solar panel cleaning is economically justified.
definition: A panel cleaning should be triggered when either: (1) meet Soiling Cleaning Threshold (2) >30 days since last cleaning—whichever occurs first.

description: Defines thresholds for high, moderate, and normal degradation based on NDI value.
definition: Panels are classified as 'High Degradation' if NDI exceeds 1.5, 'Moderate Degradation' if NDI is between 1.0 and 1.5, and 'Normal Degradation' if below 1.0.

description: Comprehensive rules for generating performance alerts
definition: Mandates that critical alerts must: (1) Reference the plant ID, panel ID and performance record; (2) Set status to 'Critical'; (3) Assign 'High' maintenance priority; (4) Set replacement priority to 'High' if performance <60% of expected, otherwise 'Medium'; (5) Mark optimization potential as 'High'; (6) Use 'ALERT_' prefix with random hash for IDs; (7) Update existing alerts within 30-day window rather than creating duplicates
